description: From Middle English cuffe, coffe (“glove, mitten”), of obscure origin. Perhaps from Old English cuffie (“hood, cap”), from Medieval Latin cofia, cofea, cuffa, cuphia (“helmet, headdress, hood, cap”), from Frankish *kuf(f)ja (“headdress”), from Proto-West Germanic *kuffju, from Proto-Germanic *kupjō (“cap”). Cognate with Middle High German kupfe (“cap”).

entries.meaning: the end of a shirt sleeve that covers the wrist
the end of a pants leg, folded up

verbs.description: cuff (third-person singular simple present cuffs, present participle cuffing, simple past and past participle cuffed)

description: 1520, “to hit”, apparently of North Germanic origin, from Norwegian kuffa (“to push, shove”) or Swedish kuffa (“to knock, thrust, strike”), from the Proto-Germanic base *skuf- (skuƀ), from Proto-Indo-European *skewbʰ-, see also Lithuanian skùbti (“to hurry”), Polish skubać (“to pluck”), Albanian humb (“to lose”).
Germanic cognates include Low German kuffen (“to box the ears”), German kuffen (“to thrash”). More at scuff, shove, scuffle.

entries.meaning: A blow, especially with the open hand; a box; a slap.

verbs.description: cuff (third-person singular simple present cuffs, present participle cuffing, simple past and past participle cuffed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hit, as a reproach, particularly with the open palm to the head; to slap.
examples: [They] with their quills did all the hurt they could, / And cuff'd the tender chickens from their food.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fight; to scuffle; to box.
